repnme.cdata!:
Yugoslavia - Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh
            Industrial Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the combined Project Completion
            Report (PCR) for the Fifth, Sixth and Seventh Industrial
            Credits in Yugoslavia. After a slow start, the technical
            assistance commitments undertaken by the Borrowers in
            respect of institutional strengthening under the Projects
            were largely met, except for improvements in the management
            information systems (MIS) components partly due to the
            existence of obsolete computer systems. The three Projects
            were successful, to some extent, in meeting their objectives
            of providing foreign exchange resources to meet priority
            objectives in the LDRs at a difficult time in the Yugoslav
            economy. The Projects had limited success in the overall
            institutional strengthening of the Borrowers. The single
            most important lesson emerging from the three Projects is
            that a sound macroeconomic framework is essential for the
            success of such projects. The Bank was unable to have any
            significant impact on the critical issues of enterprise and
            bank ownership and governance, a situation which is now
            being addressed under the Government's ongoing economic
            reform program. Other important lessons from the Projects
            include the need to ensure that adequate monitorable minimum
            financial performance standards are explicitly covenanted in
            the loan agreements to reinforce the position of the
            financial intermediaries vis-a-vis outside influences.
            Furthermore, while macro-level adjustment operations
            substantially increase the Bank's leverage in getting
            the Borrowers' acceptance for major conditionalities,
            given the short-duration, quick-disbursing nature of such
            operations, adequate supporting conditionalities need to be
            built into the investment operations themselves to ensure
            sustainability of the improvements. Finally, strong
            prudential supervision through the Central Bank or other
            appropriate means should be ensured, particularly when there
            is reason to suspect that the financial intermediaries may
            be more than usually vulnerable to outside influences.

18217954.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
The Seventh Industrial Credit Project is
            designed to assist labor intensive and export oriented
            industries through the provision of foreign exchange.
            Besides, the project involves preparation of studies to
            identify and develop projects in labor intensive and export
            oriented industries in order to help KBP and IBT increase
            their future role in the promotion of such industries.  The
            aggregate direct employment creation is expected to be about
            10,000 jobs. Other objectives of the project are to
            contribute to the institution building of the borrowing
            banks, and to encourage joint ventures and cofinancing.  The
            project also includes a technical assistance component of
            $670,000 ($400,000 for KBP and $270,000 for IBT), for
            preparation of above-mentioned studies, staff training, and
            procurement of office equipment.  The risks associated with
            the loans relate to meeting the employment and export
            targets by beneficiary enterprises.  However, provisions
            included under the loans and Yugoslavia's policies to
            foster industrial exports should reduce the risk to within
            acceptable limits.
